Violation_Type: Procedural unfairness, inadequate reasoning, failure to assess effective state protection
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board Member's decision rejecting the refugee claims was reasonable and based on adequate state protection for Roma in Hungary
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), particularly provisions regarding refugee protection and reasonableness standard of review
Application_Facts: Two Hungarian Roma families claimed refugee status in Canada, alleging persecution and lack of state protection in Hungary
Decision_Outcome: The court allowed the application for judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Setting aside the decision and ordering a new determination
Court_Ruling: The decision is set aside due to unreasonable findings and inadequate reasoning; a new determination by a different Board Member is ordered
Claimant_Status: Roma nationals from Hungary seeking refugee protection in Canada
Defendant_Behavior: Board Member demanded excessive documentation, made unreasonable credibility findings, and inadequately addressed state protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on ethnic origin (Roma) and lack of effective state protection in Hungary
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making; effectiveness of state protection must be actual, not merely theoretical or proposed
Assessment_Factor: Effectiveness of state protection for Roma in Hungary, credibility of claimants, sufficiency of evidence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of a decision by the Refugee Protection Division
Credibility_Assessment: Board Member made unreasonable credibility findings
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing Hungary fails to effectively protect Roma citizens
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of IRPA relating to refugee eligibility and state protection
Application_Basis: Refugee claim based on membership in a particular social group (Roma) and risk of persecution
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of systemic discrimination and violence against Roma in Hungary, state response (or lack thereof)
Relief_Sought: Allowance of judicial review, setting aside of decision, redetermination by a new Board Member
Governing_Rule: State protection must be actually effective, not just existent in law or policy
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to properly consider evidence of ineffective state protection
Outcome: Decision set aside; matter remitted for redetermination by a different Board Member
Decisional_Body: Refugee Protection Division (RPD) of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution and lack of protection for Roma individuals in Hungary
Cause_Description: Two Hungarian Roma families claimed refugee status in Canada, alleging persecution and lack of state protection in Hungary
Evidence_Handling: Board Member inadequately addressed available evidence on state protection and imposed excessive documentation demands
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA sections concerning fair assessment of refugee claims and state protection
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient consideration of country condition evidence regarding Roma in Hungary
Residency_Compliance: Claimants were in Canada and applied for refugee protection under proper procedures
Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of the Federal Court to conduct judicial review of RPD decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence demonstrated that Hungary does not provide effective protection to Roma citizens
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable due to flawed credibility analysis and inadequate assessment of state protection
Evidentiary_Issues: Excessive documentation demands, dismissal of relevant evidence on state protection
